climbs.name: Peter Rock
climbs.fa: G. Rink, B. Small, D. Langmade 1977

content.description:
Having 911 on speed dial is a good idea if you have a doubt of making the moves above the single Leeper bolt.  The holds are available but are cryptic and can feel loose.  Find the magical slot for your first bomber piece and continue upwards into the groove.  The climbing remains "fun" and loose through the groove/chimney.  I belayed at the obvious, secure feeling spot at the beginning of the chimney (good gear and comfortable belay).

 Pitch two climbs up the neat and secure chimney to a pseudo-summit before finishing on a short face to reach the true zenith and the original summit register.

 A single 70 meter rope will place you at eye level of the Leeper bolt but still 30 feet off the ground.  We gingerly rapped off the old bolt or you can down climb the 5.6 flake back to your packs.
content.protection: One 41 year old bolt, cams to #3, nuts, ambulance.
content.location:
Peters Rock is the first formation you will walk past to reach the others.  From the cool notch you can see the only bolt on the route just above the 5.6 flake 

 From car to base can be done in less than 1 hour.

content.description: Unprotected but decent climbing leads up to a hole in the rock.  As a quick diversion crawl through and peer out for a stellar view.  Traverse right to the obvious chimney and do an awkward step to gain entry.  Easy scrambling through the chimney leads to the summit.  Enjoy the nearly 40 year old anchor bolts as well as the ancient, tiny summit register.  There may or may not be a new, inspiring bolt to back up those rusty spinners.
content.protection: Cams to #4.  Single rope rap down.
content.location: From Bills Rock walk west into rock enclosure and Halloween Pinnacle will be the tallest pinnacle on climbers right.  Less than one minute walk from Bills Rock/Good's Folly.

content.description:
For some, the crux might be believing the start is 5.6 as it is written in the guidebook.  For some, the crux might be the start of the 5.8 finger crack.  And for some....throw away the grades and focus on the task at hand while leading this hot-rod.  You may also want to look up the definition of "folly" and understand who is Mr. Good.

 A worthy albeit potentially disastrous climb if one decides to fall.  Just remember, it's only 5.8 and you have climbed 5.12+ in the gym!
content.location: On the other side of Peter Rock (climb through the neat notch) and you will find Bill Rock and the other pinnacles.  The start is up a short but almost unprotectable water groove on the northeast side of Bill Rock.  After groove, up into small enclave and left to start of the finger crack that angles left and back right to easier climbing towards the summit.

content.description:
Pitch one is the same as Good's Folly (difficult 5.6 start) but you wander to the right towards Copperhead Spire.  Rig a belay and ponder how to stem across the gap in order to reach the summit.  Basically, don't fall and leave the gear behind because there really isn't any worthwhile placements.  The climbing is easy and short but beware of removable hand and foot holds.

 Rappel off a single bolt back to the belay station and climb Bill's Route (chimney) or down climb back to the start.
content.location: Copperhead Spire is behind Peter Rock and between Bill Rock and Halloween Pinnacle.

content.description: Start is the same as Good's Folly (difficult 5.6) and scramble right towards Copperhead Spire.  The route continues around a short corner to an obvious chimney, you can not see the chimney from the ground.  This junky gem of a chimney is hard to start and loose in the beginning but gets better the higher you climb.  Great exposure on this pitch.
content.protection: Cams to #5.  A number 5 and 6 are useful for the belay.
content.location:
Bill Rock is directly behind Peter Rock and has the following routes; Good's Folly, Bill's Route and access to Copperhead Spire.

 Rappel back to packs off shrub with rap rings.

content.description:
Another 'wonderfully hidden in plain view' area to climb. Forrest Spires named in honor of Bill Forrest are those big spires that reside on the south side of Siphon Draw. When viewed from a distance the spires merge and blend into one another and appear to be a continuation of the massive wall to the east. Upon inspection three distinct and impressive towers show their beauty, a few smaller pseudo-towers are nestled among their larger cousins. Peter Rock and Bill Rock are the largest while Copperhead Spire and Halloween Pinnacle are just slightly smaller. Your only crowds here will be sheep and vultures.

 All of these routes have the potential to be climbed in a single outing if one has the nerves to match the severity of some of these routes.  We have a strange desire towards these older Superstition routes and I have given almost all the three star rating and that holds true for most of the climbs in these mountains, the majority will disagree.
